newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - British Business Press - Oct 22.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - British Business Press - Oct 22.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company
DAILY TELEGRAPH -- WARNING ON BUDGET TAX CUT PLAN

According to a major report on the background to the forthcoming Budget by Oxford Economic Forecasting, taxes should not be cut next month because the consumer-led recovery is already threatening to stoke up inflation. The report also suggests that public finances are too weak to absorb another round of tax cuts. The report says that Chancellor Kenneth Clarke is facing a "classic dilemma' because of the conflicting need to woo voters while avoiding an upset in the financial markets.
-- PFI LAUNCHES 120 MILLION STG BENEFITS SWIPE CARD

Social Security Secretary Peter Lilley has launched a 120 million stg project to replace Benefits Agency order books and giro-cheques with a plastic payment card. The cards will be issued to 19 million benefits claimants by the end of the decade. The cards will keep electronic records of personal details and entitlement and will be needed to obtain benefits from 19,500 post offices, which will be fitted with card readers.
-- BA TO RECEIVE 16 MILLION DOLLARS FROM USAIR DIVIDEND BACKLOG

British Airways is set to collect a further 16 and a quarter million dollars from the 40 million dollar USAir is paying out to reduce the backlog in unpaid preference dividends. USAir has handed over 18 million dollars this year and the final payment of 19 million dollars could be made at the end of the fourth quarter. The US carrier froze preference dividend payout two years ago, but with the return to profit, is now making inroads. In all BA was owed 53 and a quarter million dollars.
THE TIMES
-- DEUTSCHE TELEKOM FLOAT COULD REAP 400 MILLION STG FOR BRITONS

The flotation of German phone group Deutsche Telekom could make a profit of 400 million stg for British investors. In Europe's biggest ever public offering a price range of 25 to 30 marks was announced. On Germany's grey market Deutsche options started trading at 35 to 40 marks. The UK will be offered up to 12 per cent of the shares, which represents a one billion stg stake. The offering is expected to be oversubscribed, with some 3.5 million Germans having already applied for their share quota.
-- CLARKE AND CBI UNITE TO REVIVE PFI

Chancellor Kenneth Clarke has made a deal with the CBI to invigorate the private finance initiative. The initiative will have less red tape, more flexibility of investment and occasional reimbursement of bidding costs for companies tendering for big schemes. The joint endeavour now covers deals worth seven billion stg and is a response to concerns from industry over delays and complex processes dogging projects.
-- PEARSON SHARES LEAP AHEAD DESPITE BSKYB BID DENIAL

Shares in Pearson have leapt by 33 and a half pence stg as the stock market had its first chance to react to the reports that BSkyB was planning to takeover the media conglomerate. Chief executive of BSkyB Sam Chisholm, has said that neither the satellite broadcaster nor News Corporation was in talks about making a bid for Pearson. This leaves open the possibility of BSkyB buying Pearson television's interests.
THE GUARDIAN -- EU'S TRANSIT RULES "CREATE OPEN ROAD FOR FREIGHT FRAUD'

According to the International Chamber of Commerce, European freight and transport companies are picking up a six billion stg bill for fraud perpetrated with the EU's tax and customs system. Britain's freight forwarders face costs of 500 million stg. ICC's head of commercial crime services Eric Ellen said that transit procedures inside the EU appear structured so as to encourage the proliferation of fraud.
-- IBM HAILS AN AMERICAN RECOVERY

Results show that flat revenues in Europe have led to a slight drop in third-quarter profits from a year ago for the world's largest computer-maker, IBM. Wall Street still cheered the results because they came in at the upper end of estimates. All regions, except Europe, showed a gain in sales. IBM's chief financial officer Richard Thomas gave an upbeat assessment of the company's performance. IBM's stock price has bounced around this year due to the continuing investor skittishness despite being nursed back to financial health by Louis Gerstner.
-- GREYCOAT FIGHTS REBELS

Property company Greycoat has said it will defeat moves by its second biggest shareholder, UK Active Value Fund, to force the sale of its 500 million stg portfolio. Greycoat received a requisition from nominees acting for UK Active Value to convene a general meeting of the company. UK Active will call for the wholesale disposal of the portfolio and for proceeds to be distributed to shareholders.
THE INDEPENDENT -- OFT TO CALL FOR REFERRAL OF BASS BID FOR TETLEY

The proposed takeover of Carlsberg-Tetley by Bass could be referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission after a recommendation to the Government by the Office of Fair Trading. Officials at the OFT are applying the final touches to a report that will call for a full MMC investigation and will pass their recommendation to the DTI. The 200 million stg merger would make the company the country's biggest brewer and create a business with 38 per cent of the beer market and more than 4,000 pubs.
-- LABOUR PLEDGE TO MONITOR COSTS OF PFI

Shadow chief secretary to the Treasury Alistair Darling has said that a Labour government would introduce new price controls to ensure that the Private Finance Initiative does not create huge spending commitments in future years that cannot be met. He also pledged that Labour would make sure that the private sector was paid only for risk that was genuinely transferred out to the public sector when awarding projects.
-- BP TO BUILD CHEMICAL FACTORY IN CHINA

British Petroleum have announced a 2.5 billion dollar deal with Shanghai Petrochemical Company, one of China's biggest chemicals producers. The deal is the company's biggest joint venture in China and the second substantial investment there in a year. The deal is for the construction of a plant to make 650,000 tons of ethylene in a year. Both sides said the agreement was part of a long-term partnership to use BP's expertise in technology, management and marketing which could have other lucrative spin-offs. BMC +44-171-377-1742
